ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developed reading and comprehension skills in French.

-Enhanced French Discussion Skills over a variety of French Texts, L'tranger, le petit Nicolas, et Monsieur Ibrahim.
-Enhanced French Reading Ability through French Texts
-Immersive French Environment in New Haven with 3hrs of class daily, homework. With a bit of outside reading/listening, one can truly spend most of their waking hours in French!
Written and spoken French, knowledge of French culture and customs.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: More discussions about the contents of certain texts would help with engagement.

-Strengths: Intensive atmosphere; I liken this to a gym setting, if muscles are not effectively and frequently stimulated, then they will not grow, or will grow very little at best. It is necessary for one to take their muscles towards, or to the point of failure, in order to achieve respectable strength and hypertrophic gains. I utilize the same principle for language: one has to place themselves in situations where their language skills are stretched to the limit to alert the brain that neurological adjustments are necessary.
-Weaknesses: Structured Conversations; One thing that I did not enjoy as much was that our discussions of the books often turned into mere summaries of the text; there were many times where my class started to talk more philosophically about the texts, but many of these discussions were somewhat ended by our professor in order to talk about what happened next in the book. I think that these freeform discussions could have helped our spoken French a lot if they were facilitated more often.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend it to one eager to learn French for this class is very intense.

I would certainly recommend this course to any student who wants to become fluent in French. While I am not fluent yet, the progress that I gained in the two months of this L3L4 program was indispensable. I now feel very comfortable with conversation with most anyone in French, and I think that I should be able to achieve fluency in around 6 months with consistent work, and L5. With this class, the immersive environment of host families and Paris, and a bit of extra effort (try audiobooks of books you already love in English/your native language, and paper books as well), and you should grow a lot in your French abilities. I have taken French for 11 months, and I feel close to fluent, the French program at Yale is superb.
No. I would direct interested students to a comparable language program, such as those at Middlebury, Avignon, or Columbia.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments:
Careers in France:
-I will likely try to live in Paris early after my college life, before I have a family. I will make heavy use of French in that context. I will also make my current computer software business bilingual, hence why my next product may be called Bonne Fonction! I want my products in factories in Quebec, France, North Africa, and Belgium!
